The  Project  supports  the  implementation  of  the  sixth  national 
socioeconomic  development  plan  (NSEDP6)  of  the  Lao  PDR 
and help achieve the millennium development goals (MDGs) in 
the health sector. Following the primary health care expansion 
project,  it  will  help  the  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH)  to  improve 
primary  health  care  (PHC)  delivery  in  the  eight  northern 
provinces;  and  strengthen  the  capacity  of  MOH  in  planning, 
budgeting, financing, human resource development (HRD), and 
coordination towards a comprehensive program approach.  
 
Starting from a low base, the country’s health indicators still lag 
behind those of most other countries in the region. Challenges 
include  widespread  poverty,  isolated  populations,  and  public 
sector  capacity  and  financing  constraints.  A  PHC  network  has 
been put in place in the last decade, and access to basic health 
care has substantially improved. However, the health behavior 
of the rural poor has not changed much, and demand for health 
services  remains  low.  Services  are  often  substandard  and  not 
affordable  to  the  poor.  Appropriate  services  for  women  and 
some ethnic groups are often lacking.  
 
The Government of the Lao PDR stands committed to reducing 
poverty and achieving the MDGs, and has identified the health 
sector as one of four priority sectors in the NSEDP6. The MOH 
has  prepared  the  Health  Development  Plan  (2006–2010)  to 
address  the  sector  challenges,  including  moving  toward  a 
decentralized  and  results-based  approach,  integrating  PHC, 
improving  maternal  and  child  health  and  nutrition,  developing 
human  resources,  improving  health  sector  financing,  and 
harmonizing external assistance.   
 
The  proposed  Project  is  included  in  the  Country  Strategy  and 
Program Update (2006–2008) for the Lao PDR approved by the 
Board in August 2005, and is also included in the 2007 country 
program. It builds on ADB’s previous investments in the health 
sector  in  the  Lao  PDR,  and  responds  to  the  Government’s 
efforts  to  improve  PHC  delivery  and  help  prepare  the  building

The  Project  is  targeted at  the  rural poor,  women  and  children, 
and  ethnic  groups.  The  country  is  lagging  behind  its  MDGs 
because  of  high  mortality  and  morbidity  among  these  groups. 
Highly cost-effective interventions through an established PHC 
system will help the Lao PDR in achieving its MDGs. At project 
completion,  health  behavior,  coverage  of  essential  services, 
and health system performance will have improved. Substantial 
capacity will have been built up at MOH and the provinces for 
results-based  planning,  budgeting, 
financing,  HRD,  and 
administration towards a comprehensive program approach.   

Four  risks  have  been  identified.  First,  MOH  and  provincial 
governments  must  make  difficult  political  choices  to  improve 
sector  performance.  Project  support  will  therefore  be  results-
based and participatory. Second, PHC delivery will depend on 
external  bridging  of  recurrent  costs  until  domestic  funding 
improves.  Third,  staff  lack  skills  and  work  limited  hours  due  to 
low  pay.  Fourth,  initial  project  delay  will  be  mitigated  by  using 
the existing administrative capacity of the MOH.

  I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the Health System Development Project 
to  support  primary  health  care  in  northern  Lao  PDR  and  build  capacity  for  health  system 
development nationwide. 
 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

The Lao PDR has a population of 5.6 million people, 73% of whom live in rural areas.1 
2. 
About 2 million live in the eight, partly mountainous, northern provinces. The population is highly 
dispersed, with an average population density of 24 people per square kilometer and an annual 
population growth rate of 2%, including migration. The rural population is scattered over 10,552 
villages in 17 provinces and 141 districts. About 80% of the population depends on agriculture, 
but only 4% of the land area is considered arable and permanent cropland.2 Small ethnic groups 
make  up  about  30%  of  the  population;  most  of  these  are  poor,  live  in  the  uplands,  and  have 
limited access to services and markets, particularly during the rainy season.  
 
3. 
With  the  overarching  goal  of  poverty  reduction,  the  sixth  national  socio-economic 
development plan (NSEDP6) for 2006–2010 gives high priority to reducing urban-rural inequity.3 
Average per capita income in the country increased from $335 in 2000 to $491 in 2005, and the 
annual  gross  domestic  product  grew  from  5.8%  in  2000  to  6.5%  in  2004. 4 Overall  income 
poverty declined from 46% in 1992 to 32% in 2003,5 but growth has been primarily urban, and 
rural-urban disparities are increasing. Poverty in the uplands is estimated at 43.9%, compared 
with  28.2%  in  lowland  areas.  On  the  2005  gender-related  development  index,6 the  Lao PDR 
ranked 102nd out of 140 countries; Viet Nam ranked 83rd, and Thailand, 57th.7 
 
4. 
The Lao PDR has made good progress in health indicators, but the country started from 
a low base, and with current trends, will not achieve the millennium development goals (MDGs) 
for the health sector. Child mortality reduced from 107 to 98 per 1,000 live births from 2000 to 
2005,  compared  with  the  MDG  of  55  per  1,000  by  2015.  The  maternal  mortality  ratio  (MMR) 
reduced from 530 to 405 per 100,000 live births from 2000 to 2005, compared with the MDG of 
185 per 100,000 live births in 2015 (footnote 1). Surrounded by five countries with higher HIV 
prevalence,  the  country  is  unlikely  to  halt  the  spread  of  HIV/AIDS.  HIV  prevalence  has 
increased to 1% of service women and 0.1% of adults aged 15-45 years.8 The health indicators 
show major differences between socioeconomic groups (Appendix 1).

Communicable  diseases,  malnutrition,  and  reproductive  health  problems  are  the  major 
5. 
disease burden on the rural poor. Malaria, diarrheal diseases, and acute respiratory infections 
are  the  common  causes  of  child  mortality,  often  in  association  with  malnutrition.  Besides  a 
growing HIV/AIDS epidemic, the population also faces the threat of an avian influenza epidemic. 
Noncommunicable  diseases  and  road  accidents  are  gaining  in  importance  as  well and  putting 
pressure on the limited resources for health services.  
 
6. 
The  total  fertility  rate  has  reduced  to  4.5  children  per  woman,  while  the  contraceptive 
prevalence rate among married women has increased from 32% to 38% in 5 years. However, 
motherhood has not become much safer. According to the Lao Reproductive Health Survey of 
2000,  only  23%  of  deliveries  were  attended  by  trained  health  personnel.9 Nationwide,  86%  of 
deliveries  occurred  at  home,  and  9  out  of  10  maternal  deaths  occur  at  home.  Access  to 
emergency  obstetric  care  is  a  major  problem  in  rural  areas;  where  such  care  is  provided,  the 
prohibitive  costs  of  transport  and  operations  often  make  them  unaffordable.10 The  survey  also 
reported a high rate of pregnancies among teenagers (those aged 15–19), who are particularly 
at risk of complications during childbirth—18.4% of girls in this age group were either mothers or 
pregnant at the time of the survey.  
 
7. 
According to a 2006 study of the United Nations Children’s Fund, 39% of children under 
5  years  of  age  are  underweight  (based  on  weight  for  age),  compared  with  40%  in  1990. 
Malnutrition  is  common  because  of  seasonal  food  shortages,  common  infections,  certain 
customs,  and  inappropriate  child care.  Micronutrient  deficiencies  in  vitamin  A,  iron,  and  iodine 
are  also  widespread. 11  Malnutrition  is  possibly  associated  with  as  much  as  58%  of  child 
mortality. It is now receiving more attention as a major public health problem.  
 
8. 
Under  the  stewardship  of  the  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH),  primary  health  care  (PHC)  is 
delivered  through  a  system  that  includes  village  health  activities,  outreach  services,  health 
centers,  district  and  provincial  health  offices  (PHOs)  and  hospitals,  and  centrally  managed 
vertical programs. A substantial network of health centers has been established.12 In 2004, 53% 
of villagers in the eight northern provinces lived within 1 hour walking from a hospital or health 
center and 16% were more than 4 hours away. Physical access is becoming less of a barrier to 
health  services  for  most  people.  However,  physical  and  social  access  is  still  poor  for  women 
needing reproductive health care and for remote ethnic communities in general. Overall demand 
for services remains low. Of those seeking treatment, 26% use a village health volunteer (VHV) 
or  village  health  provider;  40%  a  government  facility;  and  29%  a  private  pharmacy  or  clinic 
(section  B). 13  Family  care  including  child  nutrition  can  also  be  improved,  even  given  local 
conditions.   
 
9. 
The  Government  recognizes  the  urgent  need  to  address  this  situation.  Its  overall 
strategic  framework  identifies  health  as  a  priority  sector  for  development,  and  proposes  to 
reduce differences between urban and rural health, lower mother and child mortality rates, raise 
life  expectancy,  and  contain  the  spread  of  communicable  diseases.  In  health  and  human 
resource  development  (HRD),  priority  is  given  to  deploying  more  health  personnel  to  the 
districts  and  villages,  particularly  to  remote  rural  areas,  upgrading  the  quality  and  capacity  of 
health personnel, and improving health financing.

In addition to expanding the infrastructure network, the MOH has set up a village health  
10. 
program to improve health and nutrition behavior and provide villages beyond 2 hours walking 
from  a  health  facility  with  better  access  to  health  care  (footnote  12).    Through  village  health 
committees, local men and women have been trained as VHVs. They provide basic treatment of 
common  diseases  with  medicines  financed  from  a  drug  revolving  fund  (DRF).  In  five  northern 
provinces surveyed under the Primary Health Care Expansion Project (PHCEP), by 2004, drug 
kits had been supplied to 48% of the villages compared to 10% 4 years earlier. These drug kits 
are  now  the  primary  source  of  medicines  in  these  villages.  More  recently,  VHVs  and  union 
members  have  also  been  introduced  to  peer  education  to  augment  behavioral  change  efforts. 
The  program  can  be  improved  and  expanded  to  include  more  prevention  and  promotion 
activities, in particular for reproductive health and nutrition.    
 
The NSEDP6 identifies health as one of four priority sectors for development. It calls for 
11. 
expanded  PHC  services  to  all  remote  and  poor  villages,  and  more  village  and  district  health 
personnel. The plan is being implemented in the context of greater decentralization of authority 
to  the  provinces.  Prime  Minister’s  Instruction  01  of  March  2000  outlines  the  Government’s 
decentralization approach, with the province as the strategic unit for development, the district as 
the planning and budgeting unit, and the village as the implementing unit. The decentralization 
instruction  has  encouraged  the  MOH  to  concentrate  on  results-based  approaches  to  health 
management.  
 
The  PHC  Policy  (2000)  approach  directly  addresses  the  MDGs.14 The  policy’s  corner 
12. 
stones are (i) expanded coverage of the health service network to peripheral areas, (ii) health 
care for women of reproductive age and children under 5 years, (iii) full community participation, 
(iv) dissemination  of  health  information  to  people  in  rural  areas,  (v)  use  of  resources  with  a 
sound scientific basis and appropriate to the actual situation and needs, (vi) collaboration with 
other  government  sectors  and  with  the  private  sector,  (vii)  more  support  for  a  more  effective 
PHC program, and (viii) sustainability of health care services at every level through community 
contributions to and ownership of the services. The family, school, and pagoda will be the focal 
points for PHC implementation in the villages. 
 
The  MOH  has  prepared  the  Health  Development  Plan  (2006–2010),15 and  is  preparing 
13. 
policies, plans, and decrees for HRD, nutrition, the package of health services, and integration 
and decentralization of health services. The Plan emphasizes efforts to increase the number of 
females  and  members  of  small  ethnic  groups  among  health  workers.  The  expansion  and 
improvement  of  the  PHC  network  has  obvious  financial  implications  for  the  Government.  The 
NSEDP6 lays out the Government’s overall strategy for increasing and providing more efficient 
funding of the health sector, along with improving donor coordination. Another health financing 
priority  under  the  plan  is  making  health  services  more  affordable  to  the  poor  by  introducing 
health  insurance  and  health  equity  funds  (HEFs).  The  Government  has  also  approved  the

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Reaching Vulnerable Groups to Achieve Millennium Development Goals 

The poor use health services less than those in higher-income groups.16 In rural areas, 
14. 
households  in  the  highest  income  quintile  have  an  inpatient  admission  rate  of  42.4  per  1,000 
persons per year, compared with 15.9 per 1,000 per year for households in the lowest quintile. 
While physical access has improved substantially in the past decade, half the population lives at 
least  one  hour  walk  from  a  health  center  or  a  hospital.  Low  population  density  and  fiscal  and 
human  resource  constraints  limit  the  potential  for  improving  access  to  health  facilities,  and 
village-based health care has been introduced to complement these services.    
 
Services  for  women  and  infants  are  less  accessible  and  often  not  up  to  standard  in 
15. 
health  centers  and  hospitals.  This  partly  explains  why  there  is  less  progress  in  reducing  the 
MMR, infant mortality rate, and low-birth-weight rate. Unless rural women and ethnic groups are 
reached with reproductive health services, these targets will remain elusive. However, a major 
reduction of the MMR is achievable with basic interventions, such as teenage education, family 
planning in the villages, timely referral of reproductive complications, and surgical services. The 
issue of low affordability of care is discussed in section B6.    
 
16. 
Additional social barriers exist for isolated ethnic groups. Ethnic groups in the Lao PDR 
are  classified  into  four  linguistic  groups:  Tai-Kadai  (44%),  Mon-Kmer  (33%),  Hmong-Mien 
(16%), and Sino-Tibetan (7%). Many of these groups live in rural areas (90%), are subsistence 
farmers (83%), and are poor (46%). They use services less and are less educated about health 
matters, such as HIV prevention.17 They generally prefer to consult health staff who speak their 
language  and  understand  their  views.  There  is  a  paucity  of  health  professionals  from  ethnic 
groups  largely  because  of  comparatively  lower  educational  attainment.  A  PHCEP  pilot  study 
demonstrated that local students can be trained as PHC workers to serve in their own villages. 
 
17. 
If the MDG to reduce child mortality by two thirds is to stay on track, common infectious 
diseases  affecting  the  rural  poor,  in  particular  ethnic  groups,  need  to  be  addressed.  These 
diseases  can  be  prevented  with  simple,  highly  cost-effective 
interventions  such  as 
insecticide-treated  bednets,  better  personal  hygiene,  vaccination,  clean  water  supply  and 
sanitation, and timely recognition and basic treatment of common illnesses. However, progress 
has been unstable because of management and service delivery problems, as discussed below.  
 
18. 
 Malnutrition, a major contributor to child mortality, will also need to be addressed. When 
there are no food shortages, it is foremost a child care problem that primarily needs household 
and  community  interventions  rather  than  health  services.  The  Government  is  preparing  a 
nutrition  policy  and  plan  to  integrate  nutrition  into  PHC.  Nutrition  among  women  and  children 
can be improved through specific, low-cost interventions such as the promotion of breastfeeding 
and a proper weaning diet, kitchen gardens, vitamin supplementation, and family planning.

 2. 

Setting Health Sector Priorities 

19. 
To achieve the international goal of Health for All, the MOH gives priority to developing a 
public welfare system based on the principles of PHC. In view of the Government’s financial and 
capacity  constraints,  this  translates  into  providing  a  basic  health  care  package  for  all  citizens 
with  special  effort  to  reach  the  poor  and  near  poor.  The  Government  gives  high  priority  to 
improving healthcare for rural women and ethnic groups, and is striving to expand services to all 
villages and houses. Overall, making the health system more effective, equitable, and efficient 
entails a shift to promoting health and nutrition, preventing diseases, improving service quality 
and affordability, and reaching remote villages, in particular women and ethnic groups with high 
residual  mortality.  Doing  so  requires  a  shift  in  the  mindset  and  practices  of  planners  and 
managers, more and more balanced financing, better staffing, and better communication.  
 
20. 
The  Government  has  taken  several  policy  actions  to  strengthen  the  delivery  of  health 
services.  It  has  approved  a  reproductive  health  policy  that  includes  maternal  care  and  family 
planning  in  villages,  and  training  of  midwives  and  surgeons.  Available  and  affordable 
emergency obstetric surgery in hospitals can potentially cut the MMR by about half and greatly 
reduce  chronic  complications  due  to  childbirth.  Considering  the  constraints  of  rural  hospitals, 
several innovative approaches will have to be taken, including the training of medical doctors in 
basic surgery, and the provision of incentives to staff posted to rural hospitals where there is no 
other means of income. The Government passed a regulation to introduce financial incentives 
for rural civil servants (Decree No. 381/PM), but these incentives do not appear to be enough. 
As HIV/AIDS will continue to spread, the Government and the Joint United Nations Programme 
on HIV/AIDS have prepared a plan to widen prevention efforts to reach all high-risk groups.  
 

3. 

PHC Organization and Management Capacity 

21. 
A  major  problem  hampering  the  integration  of  PHC  is  the  vertical  management  of 
disease  control  through  central  programs,  leading  to  fragmentation  and  inefficiency  at  lower 
levels of implementation. Rather than pooling their resources and activities in the districts and 
villages, health service providers are obliged to implement vertical program activities separately. 
Much of this behavior is reinforced by donors who fund specific projects or programs and restrict 
the  use  of  funds,  equipment,  medicines,  and  other  supplies.  For  example,  the  maternal  and 
child  health  and  immunization  programs,  both  vertical  programs,  have  done  poorly  for  many 
years, with limited management capacity, fragmented and unstable assistance, and, for the safe 
motherhood program, an inability to scale up. Their integration in PHC has been slow.    
 
22.  With  the  ongoing  decentralization,  the  roles  of  provincial  and  district  governments  are 
less  clear.  There  is  a  mismatch  between  the  responsibilities  of  provincial  and  district  health 
managers and their resources. Limited local stewardship and involvement in sector performance 
further  impede  the  ability  of  health  managers  to  respond  to  public  demand.  Because  of  the 
implications and risks involved, competent provincial health managers are often reluctant to take 
initiatives to improve services. 
  
District  managers,  to  varying  degrees,  lack  capacity  in  such  areas  as  planning  and 
23. 
budgeting,  financial  management,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation.  Managers  are  often  doctors 
or medical assistants without appropriate management training. A new generation of energetic- 
managers  is  emerging  in  the  districts,  but  most  have  received  only  short-term  management 
training.  Almost  all  provincial  health  officers  now  have  a  master’s  degree  in  public  health,

compared with only about half in 1999.18 But only a few MOH officers have nonmedical training 
in such areas as health economics, administration, and HRD.  
 
24. 
The  current  organizational  structure  and  limited  management  capacity  in  the  health 
system  have  serious  implications.  National  health  policies  and  regulations  are  often  not  fully 
implemented  by  local  governments.  Facility-based  and  outreach  services  are  fragmented, 
irregular, and of poor quality, resulting in a loss of public confidence. Also given the uncertain 
benefit of using public services, associated costs of services are often unacceptable. The MOH 
plans to move toward provincial results-based programs to integrate programs and services and 
improve  ownership,  accountability,  and  flexibility.  But  management  training,  advocacy  among 
stakeholders,  pilot-testing,  and  supporting  administrative  and  fund  flow  arrangements  will  be 
needed to achieve this goal.  
 

4. 

Improving Staff Performance 

25. 
The  NSEDP6  and  the  PHC  policy  draw  attention  to  the  issue  of  health  service  quality. 
The  performance  of  health  facilities  is  affected  by  inappropriate  staffing  or  understaffing.  The 
high  ratio  of  doctors  to  other  medical  staff  in  health  facilities  leads  to  health  system 
inefficiencies. There is one doctor for every 1.7 mid-level staff instead of the stated MOH goal of 
three to four nurses per doctor, and one to two nurses per medical assistant. At the same time, 
however, surveys show that one third of the district hospitals are without a doctor (footnote 13).  
 
26. 
PHC services are also affected by the type of training that health professionals receive. 
The  past  emphasis  on  training  sufficient  numbers  of  health  staff  has  had  implications  for  the 
quality of the staff. Despite their participation in several in-service training programs, providers 
of  maternal  and  child  health  services  were  found  to  have  inadequate  knowledge,  skills,  and 
attitude to provide accurate information and appropriate services to clients.19 For lack of funds 
and opportunities for clinical and laboratory training, many medical professionals did not receive 
adequate skills beyond classroom theory before they were sent to work in health facilities. With 
the  increase  in  enrollment  of  self-financed  students,  the  quality  of  training  has  deteriorated 
further. Also, some staff are in positions for which they have not received pre-service training, 
such as nurses working as laboratory technicians.  
 
27. 
Staff management functions, such as providing regular feedback to staff, ensuring even 
distribution  of  workload,  promoting  quality,  and  encouraging  participation,  also  need 
improvement. Health center staff, lacking transport and an operational budget, only make a few 
supervisory  visits  to  VHVs  each  year.  The  problem  of  limited  supervision  at  lower  levels  is 
compounded  by  a  lack  of  accountability.  The  lack  of  equipment,  funds,  and  information  also 
affect staff motivation and the quality of services.

29. 
Cost  recovery  was  introduced  in  the  Lao  PDR  in  the  early  1990s,  mainly  through  the 
sale  of  drugs  financed  from  DRFs.  Based  on  1999  data,  domestically  financed  government 
spending is less than the contribution from user fees.20 The MOH estimates that more than half 
of  the  operating  costs  of  central  and  provincial  hospitals  and  one  third  of  those  of  district 
hospitals are now met through cost recovery. Under a new Curative Law, the Decree on Fees 
and Charges (December 2005) allows public agencies to expand the types of charges and fees 
for services, and to use revenue from fees to cover salaries and other recurrent costs. However, 
the concern is that, even with expanded cost recovery, there might be no net increase in health 
sector financing because of a reduction in the central budget allocation, as revenue is integrated 
with the formal fiscal year budget. The actual surplus from the estimated fee income will go to 
the Treasury, and actual deficits in anticipated fee income may lead to central budget subsidies 
only after a formal audit.  
 

6. 

Making Health Care Affordable to the Poor 

30.  While  user  fees  play  an  important  role  in  health  system  financing,  they  are  not  the 
solution  to  the  problem  of  underfunding  for  the  recurrent  costs  of  health  facilities.  Studies 
around  the  world  have  shown  that  user  fees  at  public  facilities,  even  with  accompanying 
exemption schemes for the poor, deter the poor from using health services.  
 
31. 
Low affordability of services, especially for the poor, is believed to be a major cause of 
underutilization of services in the Lao PDR. The income disparity between the poor and nonpoor 
has  increased,  and  the  cost  of  health  care  has  gone  up  substantially  over  the  past  several 
years. The introduction of cost recovery for drugs is likely to have made health care even less 
affordable, and the new Decree on Fees and Charges under the Curative Law may exacerbate 
matters.  While  the  poor  are  unable  to  pay  for  services,  there  is  not  enough  public  finance  to 
provide them with free services.  
 
32. 
Households obtain about 90% of their medicine needs through out-of-pocket spending. 
This implies that free medicines are very limited in the health system and the poor may not be 
getting the medicines they need. A market is thus created for cheap counterfeit drugs that are 
unsafe and contribute to drug-resistant diseases. Exemptions for the poor are supposed to be 
covered  by  the  DRF  and  government  contributions.  According  to  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) estimates, exemptions for hospital services range between 2.2% and 21.1% of the DRF. 
This level of funding is not enough to cover the needs of the poor.

C. 

Lessons  

34. 
ADB, the World Bank, and bilateral agencies have assisted the Government of the Lao 
PDR in putting in place a basic network of hospitals, health centers, and village activities, and 
PHC coverage has improved substantially. The PHC Project21 was aimed at expanding access 
to  basic  health  services  through  health  centers  in  two  provinces  and  was  evaluated  as 
successful.22 The  well-performing  PHCEP  (footnote  12)  has  a  more  comprehensive  approach 
including  hospital  services  and  village-based  health  care  in  eight  northern  provinces,  and  the 
strengthening of provincial management nationwide. A similar approach is followed by the World 
Bank in the southern provinces.           
 
35. 
A  major  issue  under  the  PHCEP  was  how  to  shift  focus  from  inputs  (in  particular,  civil 
works)  to  outcomes,  given  the  challenge  of  navigating  complex  procurement  procedures  to 
ensure quality inputs. It was felt that technical staff should preferably not be involved in project 
administration but concentrate on outcomes. The PHCEP proved its flexibility by making some 
adjustments when a shortfall in indicators, in particular for immunization, was noted.  
 
Experience  in  the  PHCEP  demonstrated  the  difficulty  of  integrating  the  centrally 
36. 
managed  vertical  health  programs  at  provincial  and  district  levels.  Essentially,  two  factors 
accounted for this difficulty. Vertical programs typically do  not allow for sharing resources and 
pooling funds, making joint activities difficult, and PHC is often perceived as a vertical program 
itself. Strong provincial leadership can, however, foster greater integration of health programs.  
 
37. 
The  PHCEP  showed  the  effectiveness  of  using  a  geographic  information  system  in 
health service zoning to plan the location of new health centers. This approach greatly reduced 
the number of health centers that needed to be built, and optimized the catchment area for each 
health  center,  thereby  making  the  investments  more  efficient.  In  addition,  a  village  health 
program  was  added  to  improve  access  for  villages  located  more  than  2  hours  walking  from  a 
health facility.   
 
38. 
To find staff for remote health centers, under PHCEP, school students living near health 
centers  were  selected  and  provided  with  vocational  training.  This  practice  produced  health 
workers who were integrated and able to thrive in the local community. The recruits committed 
to  working  in  the  health  center  for  several  years.  Given  the  low  school  attainment  in  these 
locations,  about  one  third  of  trainees,  especially  among  the  women,  were  first  given  general 
education  to  qualify  for  vocational  training.  The  MOH  is  now  extending  this  approach  to  other 
cadres.

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  health  and  nutrition  in  the  Lao  PDR,  particularly 
44. 
among the poor, women and children, and ethnic groups in the eight northern provinces. Its aim 
is to improve health and nutrition behavior and use of health services and make the provincial 
health system more effective, efficient, and equitable in delivering PHC.  
 
45. 
The objectives of the Project are (i) to improve PHC delivery, particularly for vulnerable 
groups, in the eight northern provinces, and (ii) to strengthen MOH capacity for health system 
development  nationwide,  including  planning  and  budgeting,  financing,  HRD,  and  coordination. 
The  Project  has  two  corresponding  components  and  is  based  on  a  two-phased  PHC 
development  concept  covering  8 years,  with  the  Project  supporting  the  first  phase  of  4  years 
(2007–2011). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 3.  
 
The  Project  is  set  within  the  framework  of  the  NSEDP6  and  PHC  policy,  and  supports 
46. 
their expected outcomes, priorities, and plans. It will contribute to the improvement of key health 
indicators  to  achieve  the  MDGs  in  the  medium  term,  and  to  health  system  development  to 
sustain health benefits in the longer term. The ADB-supported PHCEP and other projects in the 
eight northern provinces helped establish a considerable network of health facilities. The MOH 
has  requested  ADB  to  help  improve  the  functioning  and  use  of  the  PHC  network  while 
expanding PHC to remote populations without such services. About 19 out of 62 districts in the 
eight northern provinces still have substantial populations living in social and physical isolation.  
 
47. 
The MOH is moving from a traditional, input-driven, centralized public health system to a 
modern,  results-based  health  system  with  strong  community  participation  and  novel  ways  of 
overcoming barriers in public education and PHC delivery. For PHC to become more effective, 
efficient, and equitable, and benefit those who need it most, the fragmented health system must 
be better integrated and substantially decentralized. Building on the strong relationship that ADB 
has formed with the MOH in health system development over the past decade, the Project will 
support  the  strengthening  of  policy  and  capacity  for  health  system  development  nationwide. 
Project support for sector policies is summarized in Appendix 4.

70. 
For provincial health systems to move toward a comprehensive, results-based program 
approach and deliver effective, efficient, and equitable care, several building blocks must be in 
place  including  strong  MOH  stewardship,  provincial  commitment  and  resources  for  health, 
integrated  planning  and  budgeting,  and  integrated  project  administration.  The  Project  will

the  guidance  of  the  provincial  committee  for  health,  provincial  health  management  teams  will 
conduct  a  strategic  planning  exercise  to  improve  their  5-year  plans  and  prepare  medium-term 
expenditure frameworks showing all likely sources and uses of funds, among others, to ensure 
adequate funding of basic public health functions and recurrent expenditures. These plans will

Project will support the division of health financing in the Department of Planning and Budgeting 
(DPB)  of  the  MOH.  Three  scholarships  in  health  economics  and  health  policy,  consulting

73. 
Given the challenges of developing risk pooling systems in the Lao PDR, cost recovery 
will  remain  the  predominant  mode  of  financing  for  non-salary  recurrent  costs.  Under  the  new 
Curative  Law  (2006),  hospitals  and  health  centers  can  now  charge  for  fees  and  hospital  stay, 
besides charging for medicines and diagnostic services. While this makes costing more realistic, 
it will also increase charges and cause the poor and near-poor further hardship. The Project will 
support  health  financing  studies  including  (i) the  impact  of  the  new  Curative  Law;  (ii)  hospital 
pricing, to set HEF reimbursement rates for services for the poor; (iii) HEF performance; (iv) use 
of loan funds; and (v) results-based supplementary operational financing. The division of health 
financing will be assisted in systematically tracking and monitoring all sources and uses of funds 
in the health sector. The studies are listed in Supplementary Appendix B.

Project Benefits 

1. 

Health Benefits 

97. 
Lagging health indicators compared with MDG goals and targets are primarily a result of 
high mortality and morbidity among the rural poor, women and children, and ethnic groups—the 
primary  beneficiaries  of  the  Project.  Targeting  these  groups  with  cost-effective  interventions 
through  an  already  established  PHC  system  is  expected  to  have  a  major  impact  on  key 
indicators in the medium term, and to assist the Lao PDR in achieving its MDGs.  
 
98. 
The  Project  incorporates  challenges  facing  ethnic  groups  in  gaining  access  to  health 
services, and the health sector in delivering good-quality PHC services. The Project focuses on 
the  eight  northern  provinces  with  a  high  ethnic  population,  and  is  aimed  at  (i)  widening  health 
center  coverage  of  ethnic  communities  by  constructing  new  health  centers  in  underserved 
ethnic areas; (ii) training more ethnic PHC health workers through special bridging courses for 
students  who  do  not  yet  meet  the  education  prerequisites  for  entry  into  the  regular  course; 
(iii) forming a new cadre of PHC officers with functions similar to those of medical assistants, to 
be posted as mid-level staff at health centers; (iv) expanding VHV training and peer education, 
in  particular  for  remote  ethnic  groups  and  female  VHVs;  and  (v)  making  the  training  course 
curricula and materials sensitive to cultural and traditional practices and equitable. 
 
On project completion, the PHC network will have improved in performance—there will 
99. 
be much more demand for services, wider coverage of essential services, and a more effective, 
efficient,  and  equitable  health  system.  Substantial  planning  and  budgeting  capacity  will  have 
been built up in the provinces. MOH capacity in HRD, economic and financial analysis, financial 
management,  and  integrated  project  administration  will  have  been  strengthened.  The  Project 
will have supported policies to restructure the health budget, services, and staff.  
 

2. 

Social and Poverty Benefits 

 
100.  Health  is  a  critical  asset  for  all  people  but  especially  for  the  rural  poor,  who  depend 
exclusively on physical labor to meet their daily food requirements and minimal living standards. 
It is estimated that at any given time one quarter of poor households in the Lao PDR experience 
an  acute  illness  in  the  family,  in  addition  to  chronic  illness.  Catastrophic  illnesses  often  drive 
families into poverty, but many families cannot afford even routine outpatient care. The Project 
is  aimed  at  making  health  care  more  affordable  to  the  poor.  The  emphasis  on  extending  and 
improving  PHC  in  the  villages  will  heighten  prevention  and  make  illnesses  less  costly.  The 
expansion of reproductive health services will reduce maternal mortality, with major impact on 
the  well-being  of  the  family  and  the  survival  of  children.  The  health  and  nutrition  activities  will 
also  lead  to  better  attendance  in  school  and  more  productive  schoolchildren.  A  summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 12.

101.  The project interventions will reduce illness  and premature death in the family, thereby 
improving  productivity  and  income.  Economic  benefits  will  also  be  derived  from  cost  savings 
due  to  increased  health  service  coverage.  Resource  or  out-of-pocket  savings  may  flow  from 
increased access to nearby health services (e.g., reduced transport costs) and more timely and

will  lead  to  other  economic  benefits.  The  Project  clearly  has  cost  implications  for  the  health 
system,  such  as  the  expected  increase  in  PHC  staff,  but  the  rational  use  of  staff  and  other 
inputs will lead to a more efficient and qualitatively better health system and better use of past 
investments. The economic and financial analysis is in Appendix 13.

Commitment to Reforms 

102.  Achieving  project  objectives  is  predicated  on  several  assumptions  and  on  the  effective

with PHC and developing the health system are closely related and share a number of risks.  
 
   
 
103.  Striving  for  more  equity,  efficiency,  and  effectiveness  entails  difficult  political  choices

stakeholders  to  reach  vulnerable  groups  and  carry  out  reforms.  Improving  PHC  delivery  and 
reaching vulnerable groups are explicitly stated goals in NSEDP6, and past projects have given 
special  attention  to  reaching  these  groups  with  reasonable  success.  The  Project  proposes 
several new strategies and interventions to further improve benefits for these groups. The MOH 
is expected to continue to provide strong stewardship for PHC. Provincial governments will be

agencies  must  be  supported  in  decentralizing,  integrating,  and  harmonizing  programs  and 
projects in support of PHC. The Project will facilitate this by carrying out participatory planning, 
helping  prepare  decrees  and  guidelines,  providing  training,  monitoring  project  activities,  and 
linking inputs with results.

104.  Domestic public funding for the health sector is about 0.8% of gross domestic product.30

need  to  give  priority  to  PHC  rather  than  to  large  hospitals  in  using  additional  funds.  Even  so, 
while the economy shows strong and stable growth and increasing revenues, external funding 
will be needed to bridge the gap in funding for the recurrent costs of PHC. The Project provides 
for several strategies to improve health sector financing (subcomponent 1.3) and use of funds

innovative  options.  After  the  Project,  the  MOH  is  expected  to  be  able  to  absorb  the  resulting 
additional recurrent cost (see Appendix 13, para. 20).

birth. Harmful practices (such as discarding colostrum) and other food taboos for pregnant women 
reduce  disease  resistance  for  newborns  and  increase  malnutrition.  Micronutrient  deficiencies 
further  hinder  child  development.  Vitamin  A  capsules  now  reach  only  29%  of  children  under  5 
years.  According  to  the  United  Nations  Children  Fund,  based  on  initial  data  of  the  2006  multiple 
indicator cluster survey, anemia is 48.2% for children under 5 years of age and 31.3% among adult 
females. In 2000, 75% of households were using iodized salt.  
 
5. 
The prevalence of HIV  had reached 1.0% among service women and 0.1% in the general 
adult population by the end of 2005, from nil in 1990, and may be doubling every 2 years. Of the 
identified  1,827  HIV-positive  cases  in  2005,  60%  were  male,  40%  female.  More  than  77%  were 
between 20 and 39 years of age. For cases where  the mode of transmission was known, 94.8% 
were due to heterosexual intercourse and 3.9% to mother-to-child transmission (footnote 8, main 
text).  Several  determinants,  such  as  poverty,  changing  social  patterns,  low  population  concern, 
migration, communication, neighboring countries with epidemics, and limited control capacity, favor 
an advancing HIV/AIDS epidemic. For example, the Government reported an HIV infection rate of 
more than 6% among 1,000 young people returning from seasonal work in Thailand. 
 
The country has had several outbreaks of avian influenza in poultry, including one in 2006. 
6. 
Two human cases have been identified so far. The threat of a new human influenza virus requires 
major  investment  in  preparedness.  Increasing  demand  for  expensive  medical  services  for  non-
communicable diseases and traffic accidents puts further pressure on limited resources.

7.

The  Committee  on  Planning  and  Investment  has  identified  72  “poor”  districts  throughout  the

million people) are classified as “poorest.” In the eight northern provinces, 60.7% of all districts are 
poor and 44.3% poorest.

11.

small-scale  water  and  sanitation,  and  also  coordinates  multisectoral  programs  such  as  those  for

hygiene  and  prevention,  curative,  organization  and  personnel,  planning  and  budgeting,  food  and

Sector Organization  

Regional  hospitals  provide  a  wider  range  of  specialist  services  and  are  also  centers  for 
12. 
training  and  technical  supervision.  Under  the  provincial  committee  for  health  of  the  provincial 
government,  the  provincial  health  office  plans,  implements,  supervises,  and  monitors  PHC 
programs in the province. In each province, a PHC coordination office under the provincial health 
officer has responsibility for PHC activities.  
 
13. 
Under  the  district  health  committee,  the  district  health  office  supervises  services  in  the 
district and the village health program to ensure regular and good-quality service to the population. 
District hospitals have been divided into two levels. Surgeries can be done in type A hospitals but 
not in type B hospitals.  
 
14. 
Health centers have also been divided into types A (large) and B (small). The functions of 
the health centers are prevention, health promotion, and the diagnosis and treatment of diseases 
within their capacity. Like hospitals, health centers manage drug revolving funds to sustain service. 
Under the supervision of the district health office, the health center supervises and monitors village 
healthcare providers, and coordinates between village and district.

Primary Health Care Delivery 

16. 
In  2001,  there  were  309  registered  private  clinics,  mainly  urban  and  mostly  run  by  public 
health  staff  after  office  hours.  There  are  very  few  private  clinics  in  the  eight  northern  provinces. 
Most of those that do exist have only basic equipment. Houaphan and Phongsali provinces have 
no  recorded  private  clinics  at  all.  In  2001,  there  were  2,132  registered  private  pharmacies  in 
Lao PDR.  There  are  also  many  unlicensed  drug  shops  and  a  host  of  illicit  private  drug  vendors. 
The sale of poor-quality and fake drugs, in particular for infections, is a major problem.

17.

included. In remote areas, where it would be highly inefficient to build fixed health facilities, VHVs 
are  the  only  feasible  source  of  PHC  services  (see  figure).  Their  presence  in  the  villages  has

given many ethnic villages access to health services within less than 1 hour. However, VHVs need 
more training, in reproductive health, nutrition promotion, and other areas.  
 
18. 
A  study  on  the  use  of  health  facilities,  done  during  the  project  preparatory  technical 
assistance  for  the  PHCEP  in  2000,  found  that  expanding  the  health  facility  network  through  the 
construction  of  health  centers  in  two  provinces  from  1995  to  2000  had  increased  the  outpatient 
utilization  rate  in  their  administrative  areas  from  16%  to  33%  in  Xiangkhouang,  and  from  8%  to 
27%  in  Oudomxai.7  According  to  the  PHCEP  Household  Survey  in  2004,  rural  households in  the 
highest  quintile  have  an  inpatient  admission  rate  of  42.4  per  1,000  persons  per  year,  compared 
with 15.9 for rural households in the lowest quintile. 
 
19. 
The  quality  of  PHC  services  is  particularly  problematic.  Many  health  workers  cannot 
diagnose  and  treat  common  diseases  such  as  malaria,  diarrhea,  and  acute  respiratory  infections 
according to the standards required in Lao PDR. At health facilities only about 20% of children with 
diarrhea receive adequate treatment and counseling (i.e., continued breast-feeding). Some of this 
insufficiency  stems  from  a  lack  of  qualified  teachers  with  field  experience  and  familiarity  with 
modern teaching methods. Many hospitals also lack skilled staff in such areas of health services as 
laboratory, pharmacy, blood bank, and some medical services. Also, critical shortages in recurrent 
budgets for public health facilities hamper effective and efficient operation.

The MOH has shifted its human resource development focus from increasing the quantity of 
health  services  to  improving  their  quality.  Strengthening  human  resource  planning,  management,

but  it  lacks  experts  and  facilities  in  this  field.  Workforce  planning  is  constrained  by  difficulties  in

information system and expanding its use. 
 
21. 
As of March 2005, there were 11,037 active employees in the public health sector, and 484 
employees on study leave. In addition to MOH personnel, 5,452 were employed in the military and 
police services. There are also about 20,107 volunteers or traditional health-care providers, and a 
small workforce in the 254 or so private health clinics. Government health personnel are distributed

24. 
Prime  Minister  Instruction  No.  01/PM  of  March  2000  established  the  principle  of 
decentralization  and  the  governance  of  planning  and  budgeting  (see  main  text,  para.  11).  Still, 
responsibilities and authority at the different levels of health administration are unclear. Provincial 
governments  are  often  uncertain  about  their  roles  and  responsibilities  because  implementation 
guidelines  on  decentralization  are  lacking,  e.g.,  for  budgeting  procedures.  The  responsibilities 
delegated  often  do  not  match  the  human  and  financial  resources  available.  There  is  lack  of 
analytical  and  managerial  skills  at  all  levels.  Most  provincial  authorities  cannot  prepare  medium-
term  (strategic)  and  annual  plans  and  budgets.  The  districts  also  lack  capacity  for  planning  and 
budgeting.  Moreover,  operating  funds  are  not  enough  to  establish  the  necessary  exchange  of 
information and provide the required supervision and services. 
 
25. 
Decentralized and need-based health planning is further impeded by the fragmentation of 
health management and service delivery into vertical programs. Each program has its own targets, 
logistics,  reporting  system,  and  often  its  own  field  workers  and  remuneration  schemes.  The 
aforementioned  challenges,  along  with  vested  interests  in  maintaining  control  over  budgets  and 
programs,  disincline  central  health  authorities  from  delegating  power  to  the  lower  levels  of  the 
health  system.  As  a  result,  decentralization  of  authority  is  incomplete  and  the  lower  levels  of  the 
health system are not encouraged or empowered to assume their full responsibilities. The shortage 
of  reliable  data  and  funds  for  supervision  also  constrain  the  management  of  PHC  and 
decentralization. Without timely and accurate data, health managers are hard put to identify critical 
needs  and  trends,  and  thus  to  plan and  budget appropriately.  Supervision  is seriously  hampered 
by  the  lack  of  operating  funds.  Managers  cannot  properly  supervise  and  support  their  staff.  The 
reasons  for  program  failures  need  to  be  analyzed  and  addressed  urgently.  Strengthening 
managerial capacities at all levels of the program will be one answer. Structural changes will also 
be required: programs should be integrated, and responsibilities delegated properly to lower levels 
with  the  necessary  authority,  flexibility,  and  accountability  for  decision  making.8  There  must  be 
substantial consensus building and indeed a change in the work culture in the coming years.

29. 
Public health-care facilities recover some of their costs through drug revolving funds, which 
include income from fees for medicines and supplies consumed. A markup of 25% (usually) on the 
purchase  cost  covers  exemptions  for  poor  patients,  administration  costs,  damage,  spoilage,  etc. 
Until recently, the facilities were not allowed to charge fees for services provided, other than drugs

33

 

and supplies, except for some nominal room charges for inpatients. The level of cost recovery in 
the country’s public hospitals is relatively high compared with that in other countries in the region. 
The recent Decree on Fees and Charges (PM 381, December 2005), may significantly change the 
way  health  facilities  charge  fees  to  patients  and  finance  staff  salaries,  however.  All  government 
agencies may now charge for all services and products that they provide, and use the revenue thus 
generated for salaries and other recurrent costs. But increasing prices risks making public health 
care  even  less  affordable,  especially  to  the  rural  poor.  Poor  and  near-poor  people  are  either 
exempted from fees or discharged after pledging to pay the fees later, often in installments. Even 
these  arrangements,  however,  often  compel  them  to  sell  assets  or  to  take  out  private  or 
commercial loans.  
 
30. 
There is substantial evidence that the non-poor receive most of the health sector services. 
Efforts must therefore be made to distribute the services more equitably, as provided in the policy 
statement of the Government. Among other things, there must be a greater emphasis on benefits 
for rural communities. The Government is making efforts to make health care more affordable, e.g., 
by improving cost recovery, and promoting community-based health insurance and possibly credit 
arrangements  and  equity  subsidy  for  the  very  poor.  There  are  three  formal  health  insurance 
schemes  in  Lao  PDR:  (i)  civil  servant  health  insurance,  (ii)  social  security  organization,  and 
(iii) community-based  health  insurance.  Social  security  organization  and  community-based  health 
insurance  are  small  programs  for  private  sector  workers  that  cover  only  about  64,000  people 
nationwide—well  less  than  1%  of  the  population.  It  will  take  a  long  time  to  cover  the  informal 
sector, given the current pace, capacity, use of services, and quality of care.9 
 
31. 
The  Government  is  also  striving  to  increase  the  use  of  fixed  facilities  and  village-based 
services  through  health  equity  funds  (HEFs),  among  others.  Three  HEFs  are  now  being 
pilot-tested. Each pre-identifies the poorest people in the district and issues health cards to allow 
them  to  obtain  free  services.  All  three  HEFs  are  relatively  small  efforts  to  support  the  very  poor. 
The  MOH  has  proposed  a  public  assistance–financed  system  with  HEFs  for  the  poor  and  also  a 
health loan fund for the near-poor. Such funds will also give hospitals and health centers a more 
secure basis for forecasting revenue. By removing the uncertainty of bill payments, they will put the 
health facilities in a better position for budgeting.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reducing poverty in Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR): 
 
Health  is  a  key  factor  in  achieving  sustained  economic  growth,  poverty  reduction,  and  gender  equality.  The 
Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) identifies health as a priority in its 6th national socio-
economic  development  plan  (NSEDP6,  2006–2010)  that  feeds  into  its  poverty  reduction  strategy  outlined  in  the 
National  Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication  Strategy  (NGPES,  2003).  The  NGPES’s  operational  framework  comprises 
four  main  sectors:  agriculture,  education,  health,  and  infrastructure.  In  the  health  sector,  the  priorities  include 
strengthening and improving the quality of health care at the grassroots level, particularly in underserved areas and for 
vulnerable groups, including mothers and children, and small ethnic groups. 
 
The Health System Development Project is aimed at improving the health and nutrition of the population, in particular 
the poor,  women and children, and ethnic groups in the  eight northern  provinces of Lao PDR. The objectives of the 
Project are twofold: (i) to improve primary health care (PHC) delivery, in particular for vulnerable groups, in the eight 
northern  provinces;  and  (ii)  nationwide,  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH)  in  health  system 
development,  including  human  resource  development  (HRD),  planning  and  budgeting,  and  coordination.  It  supports 
the Health Strategy (up to the year 2020) and its objectives of ensuring full health-care service coverage, justice, and 
equity in order to increase the quality of life of all Lao ethnic groups. It contributes directly to poverty reduction with its 
focus  on  improving  PHC  for  the  poor  and  other  vulnerable  groups.  Improved  health  reduces  income  losses  and 
expenditures due to illness or disease, and indirectly protects the labor force and production of food and cash crops. In 
education, children in good health and with good nutrition learn faster and miss school less often because of illness. 
The Project is also aimed at improving access to health care by the poor, the near-poor, women, and vulnerable ethnic 
groups by introducing health equity funds (HEFs).

The country has made strong economic gains over the last few years. Gross domestic product (GDP) per capita was

The Project  will be implemented  in the eight northern provinces  of  Xaignabouri, Phongsali, Bokeo, Louang Namtha,

difficult. Village-based health services need to be expanded into these areas.

Economic Justification 

This economic analysis provides justification for intervention by the Government of the Lao

use  of  quantitative  analysis  is  based  on  estimates  of  the  likely  net  present  value  of  the  Project’s

2. 
Spending  public  resources,  whether  from  the  current  budget  or  through  loan  funding,  is 
supported  most  strongly  where  resources  are  targeted  to  services  with  substantial  positive 
externalities—(i)  strengthening  the  ability  of  primary  care  to  deliver  basic  health  services, 
(ii) providing an insurance or social safety net for the most uncertain health services, (iii) increasing 
the  appropriate  use  of  primary  health  care  (PHC)  services  among  the  poorest  groups,  and  (iv) 
promoting appropriate and effective services. 
 
3. 
The  strongest  rationale  for  government  involvement  in  the  health  sector  is  its  potential  to 
contribute to more effective and efficient functioning of the health system and to poverty reduction 
and redistribution of income. Government involvement in the provision of health services, such as 
malaria  control,  surveillance  and  control  of  communicable  diseases,  sanitation,  mass  education, 
and  research,  is  justified  because  of  their  “public  goods”  nature.  Similarly,  many  health  services 
can create large spillover effects (such as vaccination for preventive health services), and produce 
greater  social,  rather  than  private,  benefit.  There  is  also  good  reason  for  the  Government  to  be 
involved in addressing market failure in the provision of health services to the poor.  
 
4. 
Although  progress  has  been  made  in  recent  years,  health  status  indicators  show  that  the 
population  remains  affected  by  significant  health  problems.  Urban-rural  disparities  exist  in  social 
indicators. Infant mortality and maternal mortality continue to be among the highest in the region. 
Notwithstanding the impact of poverty and of the situation in other sectors, public health issues can 
be  mitigated  with  adequate  financing  and  improved  performance  of  the  health  delivery  system. 
Weaknesses in the health system will continue to hamper improvements in health indicators unless 
the low and inefficient use of resources, inadequate incentives for service delivery, low capacity of 
service providers, and core issues of physical and financial access are addressed. 
 
In  such  a  scenario,  investing  in  health  is  likely  to  generate  substantial  economic  returns. 
5. 
The Project has been designed to have a systemic effect, supporting both activities that generate 
direct health benefits for the target population and activities that will affect the planning, financing, 
and  management  of  health  in  the  Lao  PDR.  The  Project  is  aimed  at  creating  the  practical 
conditions  for  the  actual  implementation  of  an  integrated  PHC  package  in  the  villages  while 
developing critical capacity for efficient management of the health system at all levels. The Project 
will focus on the needs of the poor and vulnerable, by building institutional capacity in the health 
workforce at all levels; improving the equity, efficiency, and sustainability of health-care financing; 
and improving the delivery and quality of PHC services. Equitable and efficient allocation of scarce 
resources can play an important role in improving the health status of the poor.

analysis of any form of public expenditure or method of raising revenue in view of the implications
